title: General scam red flags (Stop • Check • Protect)
summary: Most scams share the same patterns: unexpected contact, pressure/urgency, requests for secrecy, and attempts to make you click/pay fast.
how_it_works: Scammers try to catch you off guard with urgency and emotion.
They often use links that lead to fake websites designed to steal your information and money.
They may impersonate trusted organisations to make it feel ‘official’.
warning_signs: You feel pressured to act quickly.
You’re asked to click a link or open an attachment unexpectedly.
They request money, personal info, or secrecy.
what_to_do: STOP: Don’t send money or info.
CHECK: Verify using official contact details you find yourself.
PROTECT: Report scams and change passwords if exposed.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
